ent.origin: Early 17th century: from Italian, Spanish, or Portuguese, originally in the sense 'wild ass', perhaps ultimately from Latin equiferus, from equus 'horse' + ferus 'wild'.

p.def: an African wild horse with black-and-white stripes and an erect mane.
p.eg: This family, made up of the horses, asses and zebras, contains one genus with nine species.

ent.origin: Late 15th century: from French zeste 'orange or lemon peel', of unknown origin.

p.def: an African wild horse with black-and-white stripes and an erect mane.
p.eg: The five-year-old has become a celebrity since her rescue from a Ukrainian orphanage, her zest for life and beaming smile winning her many friends.

p.def: scrape off the outer coloured part of the peel of (a piece of citrus fruit) for use as flavouring.
p.eg: Chop the bacon and onion, zest the lemon.

ent.rhy: abreast, arrest, attest, beau geste, behest, bequest, best, blessed, blest, breast, Brest.
